resources.string: To view subjects, add a valid Repository URL using the + button at the bottom of the screen or click on one of your saved links in Saved Links.
There was an error when getting data from the address supplied, could be the network, invalid address, or wrong validation.

Please wait for a few seconds…making submission
There are currently no saved repositories.

In no particular order, special thanks to the following for their effort in:

 THE DEVELOPMENT
 Sourcey — the designer of the wonderful login/signup screen used.
 Jake Wharton — the designer of ButterKnife.
 Gravity(the language) — the source of inspiration for the logo.
 Ayman and Junaid Syed — the logo re-designers.

 MY PERSONAL LIFE
 Me — the designer of Tuq.
 Her — for keeping me sane.
 Them — wonderful family for being wonderful.
 Everybody — for being there.

 Send me complains/ideas through ogunyinkajoshua@yahoo.com

What is Tuq?

 A quote from my favorite TV Series: What the H is a Stiles?
 Tuq is an acronym for The Universal Quiz App(without the A, of course). It is a Q&A platform for quiz lovers, universities/colleges or high schools, employers, and the general public. Right now, it is restricted to multiple choice questions that requires no explicit input texts.


How does it work?

 This app is dependent on data sent to and from a server. On its own, it doesn't do much( truth be told, it is useless on its own ); however, there is a Desktop/PC software for Q&A administrators that are used to upload questions to a server. There is a concept called repository, in Tuq's context, it is basically like a folder/directory containing series of files. When questions are uploaded on to the server, it generates a unique web link, this unique link points to at most one repository. This link is what your administrator will give out to you. Each link contains detailed information on every question that is within its repository. 


In a nutshell

 All you need is to get a repository link from your administrator, your friends and/or an employer, then click on the + button on the Repository page, enter the link and wait for Tuq to do its magic. Each valid links are saved under the Saved Links page for use in the future.


What next?

 When Tuq has worked out its magic on a repository link or when you click one of your Saved links, you're presented with a list of question/courses. Clicking on any of the courses presents you with instructions from your administrator; if you decide to start quiz, then you're presented with time-based questions, you can slide both ways like navigating through your picture gallery in order to view your previous and next questions. When you're done, click on the Submit or Forfeit buttons on the top of the page to complete your quiz.


Saved Links

 This page lists all the (successful) repository links you have used. By holding for a couple seconds, you can delete or edit a repository name/link. You can also click on any in order to view all the questions available under it.

 My Results

 This page grabs and display information on your previous quizzes and your scores. Grading usually take around 30seconds to 5minutes before they are readily available.


Submissions(Error)

 Sometimes, submitting a quiz for grading may fail, most likely due to 2 reasons:
 1. You have already taken that quiz. 
 2. Network or server problem.
 In order not to lose your precious data and let you down, this page list all the quizzes that have been taken but failed to be submitted. You can then manually resend your "scripts" for grading.
"Not yet implemented, available on next update"
No course has been ranked yet, you may refresh to check again
